Operations on octet columns

　In TJS2, an octet column is pseudo-supposed to be an object of the Octet class, but the Octet class does not exist, and it is not actually an object of the Octet class (although using the typeof operator on an octet column returns "Octet").
　However, the octet column is regarded as an object, and some methods and properties are available.

　The implementation for octet columns is incomplete.。

length

　The length property returns the length of the octet column. Note that it is a property, not a method. However, you cannot assign a value to this property.


Usage:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 %>;
    var n = oct.length;  // 3 is assigned to n
    var n = <% 11 22 33 %>.length; // Again, 3 is assigned

'Numeric' property

　Indirectly specifying a number as a property allows you to access the octet at that location.
　The result is expressed as an octet number.
　For example, if oct is an expression that represents an octet column, oct [0] is a number that represents the value of the first octet.
　An exception will be thrown if the number is longer than the octet column or if it is negative.

　It is not possible to generate an assignment expression.

Usage:
    var oct = <% 11 22 33 44 55 %>;
    var c = oct[0];  // 0x11 is assigned to c
    var c = oct[2];  // 0x22 is assigned to c
    oct[3] = 'A'; // An error occurs because the assignment expression cannot be generated.
    var c = oct[100]; // An error occurs because the value is out of range.
